Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Acoustic Tweezing Rheometry of Biological Fluids

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1438569/1438567
This award by the Particulate and Multiphase Processes (PMP) program in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (CBET, Engineering Directorate), is co-funded by the Instrument Development for Biological Research (IDBR) program in the Division of Biological Infrastructure (BIO Directorate).

Measuring the physical and mechanical properties of biological materials and other complex fluids such as polymeric liquids poses special challenges for scientists and engineers. The properties of these materials can change owing to the contact between the material and solid walls, such as the walls of a container holding the material. This collaborative project involves the development of a new device and new method to measure the rheological properties of fluids or solids that avoid contact between the sample and solid walls. The method is called acoustic tweezing rheometry, and it uses acoustic levitation to hold a small sample freely suspended in air or water while applying a force on the material that causes it to deform. The device then reads the response of the material by recording changes in the shape of the sample as a function of time. By comparing the shape of the sample with computer simulations carried out as part of the project, the rheological properties of the material can be deduced. This new instrument will find applications in a diverse array of science and engineering disciplines.

Acoustic tweezing rheometry will be used to measure properties of active polymeric and biological fluids and soft tissue without artifacts such as contamination, biological activation or gelation due to contact with solid walls. A model will be developed for noncontact measurement of material constants through analytical studies and computational simulation. The acoustic tweezing technique will be developed and validated for measurement of material properties of viscoelastic fluids. The method will be applied to biological fluids and soft tissue, including whole blood during coagulation and collagen gel. Results will be disseminated broadly, including outreach to the biological communities that could benefit from the new method.

POR.DRECONTENT:
More than 110 million coagulation tests are performed annually in the United States alone. They cost ~$6.0 billion annually to U.S. healthcare. At present, none of the coagulation analyzers available on the market provide low volume, non-contact assessment of blood coagulation. The activation of the coagulation cascade at artificial (e.g., plastic) surfaces of such devices leads to inherent variability and unreliability in predicting bleeding or thrombotic risks. Blood sample volume is a critical issue for coagulation measurement in neonatal and pediatric patients. For example, 2 milliliters of blood (~0.4 teaspoon), a typical minimal amount collected per each coagulation test, can cause anemia in even healthy infants. 

This grant led to the development of acoustic tweezing rheometry, a unique technology that addresses the above-mentioned unmet needs. Its essence is the levitation of a single drop of clotting blood by acoustic radiation forces (acoustic tweezing) and measurement of the resulting changes in clot firmness and turbidity. Key disruptive features of the acoustic tweezing technology include 1) radically low sample volume requirement (4-6 ?l or 0.004 ? 0.006 ml), 2) increased reliability and accuracy due to non-contact measurement, 3) rapid assessment of blood coagulation status (<10 minutes), and 4) the ability to simultaneously assess temporal changes in both mechanical (viscoelasticity) and photo-optical properties (turbidity, e.g. PT, aPTT, TT tests) during coagulation. Experiments, combined with theoretical analysis of drop shape oscillation, clearly demonstrated that acoustic tweezing rheometry can reliably measure thrombotic or bleeding risks caused by abnormal fibrinogen concentration or deficiencies in coagulation factors (e.g., FVII, FVIII, FIX, FX, FXIII). We successfully used this integrated approach to assess the heparin dose response and tPA (thrombolytic agent) dose response on blood coagulation. We have validated our approach using viscosity standard fluids, hydrogels, and commercial blood plasma. 

The research supported by this grant will lead to the development of a novel instrument for non-contact measurement of rheological properties of biological and other active fluids, which will be an invaluable tool for laboratories that conduct the rheological analysis of such materials. We anticipate that this instrument will be used in industry to measure rheological properties of various fluids (oil, food products, etc.) and in hospitals to assess blood coagulation. The use of this instrument in neonatal and pediatric healthcare will help save the lives of many young children with coagulation abnormalities. Using our reliable and comprehensive single drop-of-blood analysis of coagulation will help reduce annual healthcare costs by nearly $2B in the United States alone. 

The grant provided research training for two doctoral students, two Master's students, and six undergraduate students at Tulane University. This group included women (70%) and underrepresented minority students (10%). The grant provided funds for these students to attend international and national conferences such as Annual Meetings of the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES), the Americal Society of Hematology (ASH), Biophysical Society, the Acoustical Society of America, and Scientific Sessions of the American Heart Association.
